In the above demo, we render a graph with two nodes and one edge defined in the code directly. For real scenario, the data might be loaded remotely. We prepare the JSON data for

We will get the following result with the code above:

The data has been loaded correctly. But the result is a little bit strange due to the large amount of nodes and edges. Limited by the size of canvas, part of the graph is arranged out of the view. We are going to solve all these problems now.
Here goes a part of tutorial-data.json. There are
in node data, and some of them are not in the range of
G6 will render the graph according to the position information in the data once G6 finds
in the data. This mechanism satisfies the requirement that rendering the source data. To solve the problem of the graph out of the view port partially, two configurations are provided:
: Whether to fit the graph to the canvas;
: The padding between the content of the graph and the borders of the canvas.
We modify the code about instantiating Graph as shown below:
The result from this code shows that the graph has been fitted to the canvas:
The configurations below will be used in the following Tutorial:
Whether to fit the graph to the canvas.
The padding between the content of the graph and the borders of the canvas.
Whether to activate the global animation.
The set of graph interaction modes. This is a complicated concept, refer to

The style properties of edges in different states except for default state. Such as hover, select.
